'Euglenoids' (or 'euglena') are one of the best-known groups of flagellates,
commonly found in freshwater especially when it is rich in organic materials,
with a few marine and endosymbiotic members. Most euglenids are unicellular.
Many euglenids have chloroplasts and produce energy through photosynthesis, but
others feed by phagocytosis or strictly by diffusion. They belong to the phylum
'Euglenophyta', and their cell structure is typical of that group.

Euglenids are thought to descend from an ancestor that took up green algae by
secondary endosymbiosis.
